message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, enlarged prostate on digital rectal examination, and elevated PSA level suggest a possible diagnosis of prostatic carcinoma. The most appropriate next step in management is to perform a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Cystoscopy and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis are not indicated at this time. Repeat PSA level in one year is also not appropriate as the patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over the past 6 months.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) with a possible malignancy as indicated by the elevated PSA level. The next step in management would be a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to confirm or rule out prostate cancer. Repeat PSA level in one year would only delay the diagnosis and treatment, while cystoscopy and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis would not be the most appropriate next steps in management for BPH with possible malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The PSA level is elevated, which is a risk factor for prostate cancer. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to rule out prostate cancer. Cystoscopy is not necessary at this point, and repeating the PSA level in a year may delay diagnosis of prostate cancer. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated for BPH or prostate cancer diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and finding of a diffusely enlarged prostate with a firm nodule in the right posterior lobe is highly suggestive of prostate cancer. The most appropriate next step in management is a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to confirm the diagnosis. Cystoscopy is not needed for diagnostic purposes in this case. Repeat PSA level in one year is not recommended due to the likelihood of cancer, and a CT scan is not necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and results from digital rectal examination and PSA level suggest a high likelihood of prostate cancer. Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is the most appropriate next step in management to confirm the diagnosis. Cystoscopy is used to visualize the bladder and urethra but would not provide information on the prostate. Repeat PSA level in one year is not appropriate given the high likelihood of cancer. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is useful for staging after diagnosis is confirmed, but not for initial evaluation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and the digital rectal examination shows a nodule in the right posterior lobe of the prostate. The elevated PSA level suggests the possibility of prostate cancer. Therefore, a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is the most appropriate next step in management. Cystoscopy and CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis are not indicated for this issue. Repeat PSA level in one year may delay diagnosis and treatment of possible prostate cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of urinary obstruction, an enlarged prostate with a nodule, and an elevated PSA level, which suggests a possible prostate cancer. The most appropriate next step in management is transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy to obtain a tissue sample for further evaluation. The other options are not necessary at this time or would not provide useful information for diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, DRE findings, and PSA level indicate a high probability of prostate cancer. Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is the most appropriate next step for further evaluation. Cystoscopy is not indicated in this scenario. Waiting a year to repeat the PSA level may miss the opportunity for early detection and intervention. CT scan may be useful in advanced cases but not as an initial step.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and examination findings suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), but the elevated PSA level indicates a possibility of prostate cancer. Therefore, a transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is the most appropriate next step in management to determine if there is malignancy present. Cystoscopy is not necessary for evaluation of BPH, and repeating the PSA level in one year would delay necessary evaluation for possible cancer. CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis is not indicated at this stage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The PSA level is elevated, which could be due to BPH or prostate cancer. Transrectal ultrasound-guided prostate biopsy is needed to further investigate the possibility of prostate cancer. Cystoscopy is not useful in diagnosing BPH or prostate cancer. Repeat PSA level in one year or CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis are not appropriate next steps in management.
